div.head:
Embleme 44. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Typhon kills weeweOsyris by deceiptdeceit, and dispersethdisperses the parts of his body on
all sides, but the famous Isis gathered them together.

lg.l: Ægypt, weeweOsyris, all the weeweSunne o'thof the wise:
By cruellcruel Typhon, all together weeweputt:
But the productive part is lost i'thin the Sea,
For Sulphur Sulphur's father's fled away.

div.head: Discourse 44.
div.ab:
The allegory of weeweOsyris weewewee have weeweelswhere (namely in the first
booke of weeweHieroglyphicks) reduced to its true weeweoriginall, which is
Chymicall, and fully explaindexplained it: Wherefore here to repeat the
same things (though the same things ought to be spoken of the-
same things) weewewee judge superfluous: but weeweneverthelesse weewewee will
here forme a parallellparallel discourse, which will weeweallwayes be and weewere
maine within the prisons of that ancient weeweChymy, which is solely
decanted and decipered by the weewePoetts: Will you weeweperswade weewemee-
that weeweOsyris was a God, or King of the weeweÆgyptians? I will not weewebe
leive, though you weeweperswade weewemee to weewebeleive; For weewedoggs (as it is in-
the Proverb) smell weewefarre otherwise, weewefarre otherwise Swine: I weewedoe
plainly deny him to be a God, and you will ascent to weewemee, weeweunlesse
you be a heathen, or of an opinion contradictory to right reason:
And that weewehee was weewenoe King, is demonstrated by all the circum
stances which are weeweelswhere considered: The weeweSunne weewehee is, but-
Philosophicall, the name of which being in many authors often at
tributed to it, the vulgar, who know weewenoe other light but that of the-
world, have interpreted for it. The Philosophers weeweSunne weewehath denomi
nation from the weeweSunne of the World, because it contains the weewepropertyes
of nature descending from that weewecælestiall weeweSunne, or weeweagreable to it: weeweOsyris
therefore, Dionysus, Bacchus, Jupiter, Mars, Adonis, weeweŒdipus, Perseus, Achil
les, Triptolemus, Pelops, Hippomenes, and Pollux are the weeweSunne: but-
Isis, Juno, Venus, the mother of weeweŒdipus, Danaë, Deidamia, Atalanta,
Helena, the weeweMoone; as weeweallso Latona, Semele, Europa, Leda, Antiope-
Thalia. And these are the parts of the compound, which before ope
ration is called Stone, and by the name of every weewemetall, Magnesia:-
After operation, Orcus, Pyrrhus, Apollo, ÆsculapiusEsculapius. The adjuncts are-
Typhon, Python, the Boar: The Artists are Hercules, UlissessUlysses, Jason,-
Theseus, Pyrithous: The weewelabours and perillsperils, which were undergone by
these artists, are innumerable: The weewelabours of Hercules, the weeweerrours of
Ulysses, the perillsperils of Jason, the attempts of Theseus, and the remora's of
Pyrithous may be seen: This is the great volume of matter and doc
trine, through which in every page Vulcan, Mercury, and weeweSaturne weewedoe
runne backwards and forwards, the first, as the father and cause of all,
without which nothing is effected, the second, as the matter and weeweforme,
the third, as the efficient. Sol takes his sister Luna to wife: Jupiter Juno,
as weeweSaturne Rhea, and weeweOsyris Isis: weeweDionysus is rippdripped out of his mother Se
mele being burnt by the lightening of Jove to be matured in the-
thigh of Jupiter his father, ÆsculapiusEsculapius out of Coronis his Mother: weeweDio
nysus coming to maturity weeweshews men a new way of drinking wine, un
dertaking an expedition even to the weeweIndyes; weeweOsyris and Triptolemus,
the sowing and use of fruit, ÆsculapiusEsculapius, the administration of Me
Discourse 44.
dicine: weeweDionysus soeso weewecalld by the Greeks, is Bacchus with the Romans,-
with the weeweÆgyptians weeweOsyris, with the Syrians Adonis. weeweŒdipus weewekilld his father
and weewemarryd his mother; Perseus slew his Grand=father, Typhon his bro
ther weeweOsyris, a Boar Adonis, Ceres the weewenurce of Triptolemus his father
Eleusius; Hippomenes obtainedovercame Atalanta by a golden apple. Tantalus
the father of Pelops obtained Hippodamia by the dispute of a ChariottChariot.
Osyris was weewecutt in weewepeices, and weewejoyned together weeweagaine by Isis his mother,
sister, and wife. The child Pelops was weeweboyld and dressddressed, and his shoulder
eaten by Ceres, and weeweagaine restordrestored to life, an ivory shoulder being added:
Achilles and Triptolemus were put under coals of fire by night, and in
the day time nourished with weewemilke, Achilles by Ceres his weeweNurce, TriptoAchillis
lemus by his mother Thetis: Achilles and Helena were the causes of the
Trojane weewewarre, 1 Achilles, 5 as 6 impulsive, 4 Helena, 2 as 3 efficient; Helena was
hatchdhatched of an weeweegge, and at the weewenuptialls of Peleus and Thetis, from whom
Achilles descended, the apple of Eris, the first cause of the rape of-
Helena, was weewethrowne about. Pollux was with the Argonauts, who (if they
lived) are præsupposedpresupposed to have lived near fifty years before the weewebe
gining of the weeweTrojane weewewarre, and Helena with Pollux came both
out of one weeweegge; Helena therefore was an old woman when she was
ravishdravished by Paris: Medea was weewemarryd to Achilles in the Elysian feildsfields,
then an old toothlessetoothless woman: weeweunlesse perhaps weeweShee restored youth to
herselfe, as weeweShee did to ÆsonAeson, the father of Jason, and as Ceres to Pe
lops, for which reason weewehee is weewesayd to become twice young: Perseus weewere
ceivd a flying horse from Pallas, and in recompence brought her
the head of Medusa, to weewewhome Mercury gave a Semitar, and
other Gods other weapons; Ceres gave Triptolemus a chariot-
with flying Dragons: When Pallas was weeweborne of Jupiters weewebraine,
as weeweallso when Sol lay with Venus it rained gold at Rhodes;-
And Jupiter in the weeweforme of a golden shower had coition with
Danae, as a SwanneSwan compressed Leda, as a Cuckow his Sister-
Juno, as a Bull Europa, as a SatyreSatyr Antiope, and soeso there
is cohærentecoherent in all. . . . . . . . . .
